topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack® Carrier Grade (Alpha): Install Helion OpenStack

titlealts.searchtitle: HP Helion OpenStack® Carrier Grade (Alpha): Install HP Helion OpenStack

body.p: To install of HP Helion OpenStack:

section.title: Create blank VMs for the installation

li.p: Use a tool such as KVM virt-manager to create three blank VMs (no operating system) on the KVM host, called ccn1, ccn2, and cpn1 using the xml files [ccn1.xml, ccn2.xml, ccn3.xml
Create three blank VM image files and resize them using the following commands:

codeblock.codeph:
touch /var/lib/libvirt/images/ccn1.img touch /var/lib/libvirt/images/ccn2.img touch /var/lib/libvirt/images/cpn1.img
qemu-img resize /var/lib/libvirt/images/ccn1.img +20G qemu-img resize /var/lib/libvirt/images/ccn2.img +20G qemu-img resize /var/lib/libvirt/images/cpn1.img +20G

li.p: Verify the size of the blank images using the following command:
Provision the virtual machines using the following commands:

codeblock.codeph:
virsh define ccn1.xml virsh autostart ccn1 virsh start ccn1
virsh define ccn2.xml virsh autostart ccn2 virsh start ccn2
virsh define ccn3.xml virsh autostart ccn3 virsh start ccn3

section.title: Configuring the installation environment
section.p: The process for deploying HP Helion OpenStack includes populating HLM node with required files, enabling Cobbler for PXE booting.
Cobbler is a Linux installation server.

li.p: Copy the cg-hos.tar.gz.gpg file and HLM node image file (cg-hlm.qcow2) to the /root directory on the KVM host.
Decrypt and extract the file using the following command:

codeblock.codeph: gpg -d cg-hos.tar.gz.gpg | tar -xzvf - (password to decrypt: cghelion)

li.p: This will extract following folders:

ul.li: hlm-files (includes hlinux distro to be pxe booted)
cg-hlm (includes source code to populate environment on HLM and deploy cloud)

li.p: Populate HLM node with required contents using the following command:
This command syncs the debian and pip files in the packages directory onto static repo on HLM node.
Run the following command to configure Cobbler:

codeblock.codeph: ./hlm_configurecobbler.sh <eth1 pxe ip of HLM node> <netmask> <gateway> <dhcp start address> <dhcp end address>

li.p: You will be prompted with following questions:
What is the IP address for this boot server virtual machine? This is the IP address of the eth1 PXE interface of the HLM node

p.i: What is the netmask for this boot server virtual machine?
What is the IP address of the default gateway for network?
What is the starting IP address for your dhcp range?
What is the ending IP address for your dhcp range?

li.p: This command restarts networking. If you SSH session gets disconnected, you will need to restart the session to the HLM console.
Use the following command to import the hlinux distribution into Cobbler.
At this point Cobbler is up and running.
Use KVM virt-manager to restart the VMs you created previously: ccn1, ccn2 and cpn1. Make sure you select network pxe boot before restarting.
Once the nodes start PXE booting, set the boot order back to hard disk to avoid repeated cycles of pxe boot.

section.p: If you want to login onto any of the client VMs, use credentials root/iforgot

section.title: Prepare the environment for installation
section.p: At this point, the networking settings and PXE clients are ready to proceed deploy the HLM VM on those 3 nodes using CLM network.

li.p: Change to the HLM node:
Prepare environment for the installation
This command brings new code from kenobi source folders and will install the code into /opt/share/hlm on HLM node.
Create new cloud template:
This command creates a directory in root folder.
Example: hnewcloud hlmcloud demo will create ~/juno cloud config files from the demo sample.
Update cloud template JSON files:
a. Change to the new cloud directory you created
b. Modify the serverConfig.json with the IP address of the PXE eth1 interface of the cloud nodes.
c. Modify environmentConfig.json to add details of CLM network:

NOTE: The HP Helion Configuration Processor will assign the first address of the CLM address range to itself for serving python and debian repositories.Make sure that you set the first IP address of the CLM range for the eth2 (CLM) address of the HLM node.
d. Modify ccp-1x3-as.json to specify the number of controllers; enter 2.
e. Modify the definition.json file to specify the number of compute nodes; enter 1.
"count": 1, //number of computes in the resource pool

section.p: For baremetal environment or virtual env with fancy networking - you will have to edit the logical network and environment config json files to represent your desired configuration.
